cyclone.name: NICOLE
cyclone.current_location: about 555 miles E of the northwestern Bahamas
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to turn northwest today, then move west-southwest Tuesday–Wednesday, reaching the northwestern Bahamas Wednesday and crossing the Florida Peninsula toward the eastern Gulf of Mexico late Wednesday night through Thursday; then curving north toward Georgia/South Carolina.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: east-central Florida coast (near or north of West Palm Beach) late Wednesday night, 09–10 Nov 2022

weather_observation.watch_coast: Tropical Storm Watch in effect for the northwestern Bahamas (Andros Island, New Providence, Eleuthera, Abacos, Berry Islands, Grand Bahama Island, Bimini).
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northwestern Bahamas, the entire Florida Peninsula (both east and west coasts), and the southeastern U.S. coast to the Carolinas.
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Yes – heavy rainfall of 2–4" with locally higher totals possible across west-central Florida
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Possible – surge potential exists along the west-central Florida coast including Tampa Bay if on-shore Gulf fetch develops late Thursday
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (≥39 mph) have a 43 % chance; brief strong gusts could exceed 50 mph (10 % chance).
weather_observation.storm_surge: Elevated water levels of 2–4 ft above normal tides are possible in and near Tampa Bay if the center moves into the eastern Gulf Thursday night–Friday.
weather_observation.rainfall: Periods of heavy rain beginning late Wednesday night through Thursday night could total 3–6 inches in the Tampa Bay region, producing localized flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: High seas and dangerous marine conditions in Tampa Bay and the approaches; possible tornadoes in outer rainbands during landfall phase.
